As it has evolved from a 10-minute cabaret piece, through a short film Bousman made in Toronto, to the big screen, Repo! The Genetic Opera has gained in both guts and gusto.
Buildings and their interiors fare a lot better in this sumptuously lensed and set-designed film. That's because they don't have to talk or act.
That these boys could not fathom what was actually going on in the camps also rings true and is the reason why stories like this one must endure.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Kaushik is remarkable as Chanu, a role that demands he be a buffoonish, yet loving man, intelligent beneath his self-aggrandizing attitudes, oversized ambitions and determined cheerfulness.
The winning aspect of this adaptation of a best-selling autobiography is in the director's management of the points of view.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: After two and a half hours, The Secret of the Grain, ends, as arbitrarily as it began.
movie_title: La Graine et le Mulet (The Secret of the Grain) (Couscous) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Coming from the man who made his name as a director of often grim social-realist films such as Vera Drake, All or Nothing and Secrets & Lies, Mike Leigh's Happy-Go-Lucky strikes one as a film fantasy.
Quite a bit of honey is applied to make the awful truths palatable, but The Secret Life of Bees curtails the sappiness with performances -- especially Fanning's -- that are grounded in reality.
Utterly asinine, sophomoric, tasteless, the movie has much in common with Zucker's Airplane!, The Naked Gun 2 1/2 and Scary Movie sequels, minus the laughs.
All Together Now enthrals. It also makes you want to fly to Las Vegas immediately and buy a ticket to LOVE.
A thrilling adventure tale and teen fantasy that is grounded in real concerns about who is managing the planet.
This film rests uneasily between art and thriller, putting a huge burden on the actors, especially Julianne Moore, to convey the larger meaning of the story.
Tell No One is a thoroughly absorbing whodunit with more twists and switchbacks than the Le Mans racecourse.
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: No character in this turbulent sea of love crashing on the shores of misfortune is any more developed than they are in Sparks' potboiler.
Igor, like the Frankenstein's monster at the centre of its tired plot, looks like something cobbled together out of used, very used, parts.

In the hands of a lesser director, the secondary characters, including Todd's matronly Indian landlady, might have been mere caricatures. Smart production design and camerawork enhance the sense of authenticity.

French journalist Marie-Monique Robin takes a scattershot approach in her exposé of Monsanto, an American multinational chemical and biotechnology company responsible for some of the most toxic and environmentally damaging products ever sold.
movie_title: Le Monde Selon Monsanto (The World According to Monsanto) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Director Julian Jarrold and writers Jeremy Brock and Andrew Davies have not surpassed their predecessors, but neither have they done any lasting damage with their interpretation of the 1945 novel.
A costume drama with an emphasis on costume over drama.
movie_title: Une Vieille Maîtresse (The Last Mistress) (An Old Mistress) (2007)

movie_review_blurb: While there is much to admire among the subjects of A Jihad for Love, the film itself is a low-grade production that risks losing the viewer with an unimaginative sequence of talking heads.
The animated action movie nevertheless delivers -- da-dum -- more fun than a barrel of monkeys.
Nothing much happens in Alice's House, and a turning point in the plot is terribly contrived, but as sociology and maybe even a pilot for a soap serial, the movie is worth a look.
If Benson Lee's intention with Planet B-Boy was to set the record straight on the continuing story of break dancers, then his documentary has to be counted a success. With a few caveats.
With no plot to speak of, no character development whatsoever, no theme and precious little intrigue, what we have here is simply a pileup of effects. And not especially special effects.
The script has a stale air, like something that was doing the rounds for a long time before David Ross found backers to make a film out of it.
It is about as clever as one can be on a low budget with actors known only from bit parts and TV.
Less an account of hatred and injustice in apartheid-torn South Africa than it is a soap opera-ish romance that could easily be an episode of The L-Word.
It's not every director with a camera and curiosity about his fellow man who'd try a stunt like this. And it's not every viewer who'll be content just to watch and listen as the story slowly unfolds.
With all the charm of the early James Bond movies and all the heart-stopping chase scenes of the contemporary spy series ... Alex Rider heaves into view as a reluctant, but thrilling young spy.
... feels more like a 1950s cartoon.
It's easy to see from the above that The Last Kiss is a movie scripted from a male point of view to capture that elusive young male demographic.
The interplay between hard facts and the dreams that are the currency of movie actors, agents and producers that gives Hollywoodland both its glitter and its grit.
The exposition is so heavy-handed, the producers might just as well distribute a printed handout to hapless ticket buyers.
This is a story that could have gone way too far in the direction of the touching tale illustrating how kids overcome their fear of being ridiculed -- but instead maintains a buoyant irreverence.
Pulse is most cunning in its overarching theme: What Americans have to fear most are hidden dangers in their midst.
Funny, absurd, often mocking itself and always quoting cultural history.
There's only one answer to this epistolary screen romance: Return to Sender.
Cuesta entices extraordinary performances out of his young actors.
Ray's script shambles off in all directions and succeeds only in reinforcing our disbelief.
Long before the two-hour mark, Coleman's documentary begins to more resemble a photographic tour through a museum than an exploration of a living religion.
It is a story told in small moments, the camera close-up on a look, the stroke of a hand, the way a blonde thread is revealed in a husband's jacket.

Endangered as they are, burrowing owls will be disappointed to learn that their cause has been hitched to a movie with little entertainment value, let alone credible strategies to save their environment.
The latest spelling bee movie is a Starbucks Entertainment product, and it has a made-to-order feel about it, kind of like a compilation album.

It is possible to leave Brick without fully appreciating how all the pieces fit together, but still satisfied by a well-crafted tale undertaken by a director who pays homage to a film tradition in a truly original way.
Too many characters and so much plot that no single scenario ever develops into an absorbing drama.
More often than not it's the slapstick elements, predictably occasioned by gender confusion, that get the laughs.
This is a classic family fun fare, likely destined for sequelhood.
It's a half-baked movie that looks strangely dated (it was actually made in 2003), underfinanced and simplistic next to films with the same theme, like the Spy Kids series.

As a horror flick, Final Destination 3 is literally laughable.
Cantet never finds the keys to his characters in Heading South and fails to give them life beyond the politicized representations imposed on them by Laferrière.
A movie that doesn't know whether it is slapstick comedy, satire, mystery or a schlock horror flick. Whatever it is, it is highly derivative, and of little consequence.
Political intrigue, the thriving jazz-era nightclub scene and the breakdown of the class system within a city in turmoil should have yielded more engaging scenarios.

Lacking the gritty reality of the 1994 documentary Hoop Dreams, this Jerry Bruckheimer film, directed by newcomer James Gartner, converts a year in the life of a basketball team into a very conventional triumph of the underdogs.
A scantily clad premise that would at best have been a light-hearted farce goes in search of a heart-tugging denouement and doesn't find it.
Somewhere between shooting and post-production the film got chopped into tiny, bit-sized pieces reshuffled to such a degree that it becomes hard to follow the narration.
A cunningly crafted fairytale ...
The script takes the film to the edge of banality, with Hope's ceaseless pondering.
Such bizarre touches remind one of the appeal of WWE televised bouts.
Nanny McPhee has its own enduring charm, a mix of witty dialogue, pie-throwing slapstick and eccentric family portrait.
A triumph of costuming and production design over plot, theme and main characters.

The director squanders a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to film on the grounds and inside the Palace of Versailles. It's the trappings we get, in richly reproduced costumes and all-over gilt furniture, at the expense of any substance.
The cheesy soundtrack and the lacklustre acting undermine [director Friedkin's] efforts at turning an intelligent play into a scary movie.
A self-consciously directed, socially conscious film, 2:37 is too forcefully plotted to ever engage a sympathetic viewing.
[Actor] Dupuis's presence obscures some of the flaws in this film, and makes the other actors look better than they otherwise might have appeared.
Quite a few plot lines and character quandaries remain unresolved. And yet the movie makes sense as it stands. After all, one can never know what makes a psychopath tick.
This potentially saccharine weepy has an authentic ring, thanks to Jon Kasdan's script and a cast capable of delivering clever lines that sound just about right for whatever situation they're in.
Without angst or melodrama, director Robert Guédiguian has made a film that gives nationalism a good name.
A most tedious bit of filmmaking, as painful to watch as one imagines the characters' lives might be.
Offside is shocking in its revelation of the legal oppression of women in Iran. This film is also hugely funny.
[Director] Dercourt's manipulation of his characters and his imagery can be a little heavy-handed, but there's nary a wrong note in the performances of his exceedingly fine cast.
movie_title: The Page Turner (La Tourneuse de pages) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Intertwining more storylines than a dog walker's clutch of leashes, Firehouse Dog nevertheless gets them all neatly resolved, pets in the right hands and wrongdoers in the can.
It is to be hoped that Amazing Grace is not the only, or the last, cinematic celebration of 200th anniversary of abolition, for there are more stories to tell, more imaginatively.
It never pays to think too much about movies constructed to make you think.
Ultimately, the film leaves us floundering.
For all its dramatic manipulation, The Flying Scotsman succeeds, in a modest way, because it's true.

For all that Bridge to Terabithia does to encourage children to exercise their imaginations and pursue the arts, the movie's producers give only glimpses of the wonderful creatures and magical kingdom dreamed up by two children.

Director Pierre Gang can take responsibility for the uninspired scene-setting and over-acting, but newcomer Jeremy John Bouchard gets most of the blame for this film. His script wouldn't pass muster as a low-rent, daytime television drama.
[Director] Bose embeds her history lesson in a drama with authentic emotional mother-daughter conflict.
Fulfilling the strict conventions of the zombie movie, Awakening might be enough to satisfy a loyal fan base. Certainly it is not a good movie judged by any other standards.
Seidelman maintains the narrow path between ridicule and dignity in a movie that dishes out humour even-handedly, but spares the characters total humiliation.

Many elements of The Return are quite sophisticated as past and present converge and Joanna's pursuer catches her scent. It's too bad that the plot takes us into irrationality, past the point of no return.
If you really must find something to distract your children from Christmas shopping and material yearning, this one gets top recommendation for happily occupying 90 minutes at the mall.
The Painted Veil recalls an earlier era of film direction, when movies moved rather than manipulated and craft superseded special effects.
Movie sequels rarely work as well as literary serials, but the Henry and Fay movies have the ring of a satisfying trilogy in the making.

[Director] Sarin was aiming for an epic and arrived at episodic. That might have been okay if the episodes weren't so partitioned from each other, the flashbacks failing to illuminate the present action.
'As Grimm as it gets,' says the promotional tag for Happily N'Ever After. Make that grim.

Perhaps director Sylvain White hoped that this laughably melodramatic film might find its way into the pantheon of urban dance films. But seen against such films as Rize and You Got Served, it's a step in the wrong direction.
There is a lot to engage the eye and the ear in Guru.
... only needs a couple more turns of the screw to make it a more engaging narrative.
Diane Keaton has a lot to answer for in her willingness to portray Hollywood's idea of middle-aged womanhood.
How perfect that two of the most popular funny guys around, Tom Hanks and Tim Allen, speak for the lead boy-toys.

Madonna still cannot act.
Russo is a hot-stuff revelation here. It's enough to make Nicole Kidman put her clothes back on.

If you ever wanted to know how awful a Jackie Chan movie would be without Jackie Chan, this is it.

A wild, wild mess!
Fiendishly feline Jolie is stressed to impress, but her efforts are foiled by a script that keeps her tiger caged.
Practically screams 'TV movie.'
A bumpy buddy romp that's mildly winning thanks to its stars.

Geena Davis and Renny Harlin couldn't cut it with Cutthroat Island. Steven Spielberg nearly got the hook for Hook. But leave it to Miss Piggy and Kermit to discover uncharted gold in the shipwrecked-pirate genre.
Writer Robin Schiff, expanding on minor characters in a play, fails to find enough for her ditsy and ditsier pair to do.
movie_title: Romy and Michele's High School Reunion (1997)

As warm and cheery as a mug of hot cocoa on a frosty morn.
This is one Road whose gold apparently got paved over.

movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

Neither the best nor the worst, Operation Condor makes for a slap-happy medium

A little lifeless.

Dramatically moving and good-naturedly humorous, it transmits a sharp picture of humanity that inspires both awe and laughter.

A pile driver to the brain.

Slow-moving.

One coming-out party that aims to please nearly everyone.
This oft-riotous bio is the ultimate loser-makes-good fantasy.

Black Sheep is bleatingly awful as it reteams Chris Farley and David Spade, the poor idiot's Abbott and Costello, in a comedy so desperately inept it makes their previous effort, Tommy Boy, look like a minefield of high wit.
Far less plastic than most cross-dressing comedies.

As Spielberg vehicles go, Amistad -- part mystery, action thriller, courtroom drama, even culture-clash comedy -- lands between the disturbing lyricism of Schindler's List and the storybook artificiality of The Color Purple.
Gladiator pours on the usual Caesar dressing.
Despite Murphy's consistently strong performance, Metro meanders into a rather unremarkable cat-and-mouse territory.
These two vets of showbiz wars smartly play off their own iconic pasts.
A pile of recycled space junk, it alienates even while flinging body parts into the audience's yawning faces.
Like its title character, Mr. Wrong doesn't know when to quit.
Tissues or barf bag, take your pick. Personally, I was glad I grabbed a handful of concession napkins. Judging by the chorus of sniffles, I wasn't alone.
Murder is a fairly diverting game of whodunit, like a big-screen version of Clue, until it sinks into routine thriller antics and wraps up preposterously.

The spirited cast of Jamie Lee Curtis, Kevin Kline and Monty Pythonites John Cleese and Michael Palin is willing. But this tossed-together trifle about an unassuming British zoo taken over by a money-mad Murdochian media mogul is weak.
Rude, crude and outrageous.
movie_title: Don't Be a Menace to South Central While Drinking Your Juice in The Hood (1996)

movie_review_blurb: It's a familiar show-biz routine but one that's spangled with happy surprises and sharp acting.
A moronic buddy comedy with a fuzzy-wuzzy coating.
Unless you have a craving to watch a sluggish Ski-Doo race or want to admire Chase dressed as a hula dancer, consider this the cinematic equivalent of yellow snow.
Pitch Black is one of those annoyingly noisy outer-space thrillers where you can't figure out the characters' names at first, and when you finally do, they are either dead or you hate them.
A shining ensemble cast that hits all the right notes makes Brassed Off toot sweet.
A substandard ebony-and-ivory buddy pic!
The love story is pure mush, not helped by the bland voice work done by Kevin Bacon as Balto and Bridget Fonda as dainty husky Jenna.
Wes Craven and writer Kevin Williamson have sharpened the focus along with their copycat killer's knives.

The scares were sometimes cheap, but they weren't stupid.

movie_review_blurb: The humor never strikes the right champagne-bubbly tone.
While Scream has its frights, it feels more like one of those solve-the -mystery jigsaw puzzles than a real movie.
Silverstone guilelessly glides through her role like a Pam-sprayed charge card.
Just what the universe needs. A movie that forces you to fixate on Garry Shandling's crotch.
This is pretty sophisticated for so-called kid stuff.
A bush-league kiddie comedy in The Mighty Ducks mode.
Isn't all that romantic and is only half as funny as it thinks it is.

Whitaker clumsily mishandles what should be a 'you go, girl!' tour de force.

A joyless lump.

Most of the humor is about as fresh as the air left behind whenever Witherspoon uses a toilet.
A stunner with a breathtaking array of eye-teasers.
Quote not available.
Blair Witch oozes spellbinding primal fear!
A frightfully good job.
If you drop the "c" in hockey you get a perfect description of Mystery, Alaska.
The performances are uneven.
For a story about a London harlot's trials and tribulations, this is one unsexy, drawn-out dirge with only a few smirking moments as relief.
The camera fails to capture the basketball action to its best advantage, and it really isn't explained how the players become so talented so quickly.
From the opening spoof of 2001: A Space Odyssey to the end-credit yuks, MST3K:TM seizes your funny bone like a rabid mongoose and never lets go.

Despite the fact that not much of actual consequence happens during "Right Now, Wrong Then," Hong does much more right here than he does wrong.

I would have preferred that they simply had shut their naysayers down by producing a better movie.

Let's just say I have been to wakes that have elicited more laughs.

movie_review_blurb: If DuVall's purpose was to provide a snapshot of her generation, she should have sharpened her focus.

A porterhouse of a movie that touches your heart.

movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Let's just say if you are human, there is no way that Lion won't move you.

movie_title: The Music of Strangers: Yo-Yo Ma and the Silk Road Ensemble (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life is better than middling as it sidesteps the trap of simply pandering to its youthful demo with cheap laughs and silly mugging.
movie_title: Middle School: The Worst Years of My Life (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Luckily, many of the plot's maudlin pitfalls are greatly mitigated by the film's utterly infectious leading lady.
Instead of elevating the Angry Birds concept to surreal heights of insane genius, the filmmakers settle for a tale bogged down by familiar themes plucked from much better films.
Part-"Cake," part-"50/50" and a whole lot of "Beaches" ...
What started as an engaging character study falls apart when the cards that Tahir and Hannah are dealt are so obviously and overtly stacked against them at every turn.
"Dreck the Halls." "O Unholy Night." "Jingle Hell."

Although a surprising number of plot machinations from the original film remain fully intact, usually accounting for anything that seems remotely clever, what is missing is the type of hold-your-breath tension provided by good thrillers.
It fails to provide the sorts of human inter-connections and deep revelations for which director Mitch Davis seems to be striving.

I haven't been this shook up by married seniors under duress as they hang out in the kitchen since "Amour."

The flashily photographed enterprise too often becomes a blur of sound bites and slick aesthetics akin to a Nike commercial.
Sweetly-intentioned though somewhat awkwardly structured ...
Earnest can mean serious and sincere. But, in this case, it too often means repetitive and plodding.
An intimate, highly effective chiller in a confined space with an armrest-grabber of a payoff.

An account of a remarkable person should strive to be as equally remarkable as its subject, not the timid and tidy boilerplate special of a biopic that "The Man Who Knew Infinity" too often resembles.

Despite the compact running time, it is easy to feel that you have come to know-and likely admire-Elizabeth Murray.

Instead of a hearty chowder of emotional highs and lows, first-time director Alexander Janko, who also adapted the script, settles for a diluted, Campbell's-Soup version of getting one's groove back.

As comforting, low-key and unfussy as your grandmother's tablecloth.
A high-altitude soap opera, woozy with overly telegraphed peril and determined to make the audience root for a couple who clearly aren't meant for each other.

One of the better solo directing debuts by an actor in recent memory.

A mostly pleasant surprise in a year that has produced a lack of stellar animated outings.

movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There is more pleasure to be had in the dwindling returns of CMT's Nashville than in this country soap-opera.

Noisier, busier, crasser and more laugh-free than the first outing.
movie_title: The Nut Job 2: Nutty by Nature (2017)

The dialogue ("We're not so different, you and I") can sound a little ripe, but the action is appropriately brutish and impeccably timed.
[Its] familiar beats cunningly coalesce into an elaborate plot, set to Takagi Masakatsu's bustling score.
movie_title: The Boy And The Beast (Bakemono No Ko) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: British director Johannes Roberts makes decent use of the murk (the film was largely shot in a tank in London) and the sisterhood theme gives the film a broader appeal than, say, The Shallows.
O'Reilly's script has been written around the actors so the ensemble is particularly strong.
It's a waste of Frot, an actor so gifted she wiped the floor with Meryl Streep in last year's great Florence Foster Jenkins stand-off.
Writer-director Shuko Murase patiently teases out Itoh's unwieldy and dark themes of political skulduggery, military outsourcing and public apathy.
Cars 3, which picks up where the first, perfectly adequate, film left off, is by far the best instalment in the series.
These are characters. They are also animals, and when they are slain, there's a ghastly novelty to it, one that has long ago worn off the spectacle of dying humans
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It won't do much for grown-ups, but a camp slumber-party classic is born.
Continuity geeks may lament the fixing of one of Cameron's most famous gaffs.
A splendid cast work through the complications and stages of grief to provide a scathingly anti-nationalist warning from history.
A timely warning against big-block buildings with empty ground-floor shop units, nonetheless.
movie_title: Citizen Jane: Battle for the City (2017)

movie_review_blurb: This clever, nuanced drama doubles as a political allegory concerning Brazilian corruption. But it would matter, regardless. A dawning, as the similarly-titled song has it.
They don't make them like this any more.
As a high-end soap, Sweet Dreams works very nicely. The film flows down the gullet without much irritation.

The recycled plot is very much at odds with Seamus McGarvey's knockout floating cinematography, Nigel Phelps' multi-dimensional space station designs, and (Safe House) director Daniel Espinosa's aptitude for white-knuckle runarounds.
There's little here for accompanying parents or older siblings. And the film never does figure out what the smurfing point of Smurfette is.
It even manages something like a happy ending without sugar-coating the still poignantly relevant themes.Timely and heartbreaking, some 43 years after its debut.
movie_title: Angst Essen Seele auf (Ali: Fear Eats the Soul) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: The sexual politics have dated, yet conversely, Cuckoo's overlap with Michel Foucault's ideas on the construction and socio-political appropriation of madness remains potent and urgent.
movie_title: One Flew Over the Cuckoo's Nest (1975)

movie_review_blurb: The tricksy plot streamlines and improves the final messy section of the source novel, to tease and mislead even the most astute viewer.
Sweet and silly viewing for the littlest cinema patrons.
movie_title: Ted Sieger's Molly Monster - Der Kinofilm (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A lovely new addition to 2017's splendid gallery of superior art-horrors.
Good, clean - well, not clean - generic fun from Wolf Creek director Greg McLean, bolstered by a solid ensemble cast and impressive bloodwork.
The production makes charming use of the no-budget film-within-the-film and of its talented, likeable ensemble.
The two central performances, Cathal Watters' claustrophobic lensing and Anna Maria O'Flanagan's trippy cuts ensure there's quite enough black magic.
An urgently needed slap-down for the history-blinkered who say "What about all lives?" when confronted with Black Lives Matter.
It may not be the helmer's finest film, yet it darts nimbly and appealingly between its slickly delivered set-pieces.
Why, given that Sexy Fighting Robot Lady, has a Barbie body, does she bother with underpants and clothes in some scenes but not in others? Do Donald Duck rules apply?

Filmmaker Cantor has enough access to the titular hoofer's parents, grandmother and Royal Academy colleagues to unravel his mystery of his 'retirement' and to capture the precise moment when he falls back in love with dancing.
The running time - or lack thereof - is a problem, but this otherwise perfectly ghoulish exercise marks Nicolas Pesce and his crew as talents to keep track of.
Davies works Dickinson's poetry into the script, resulting in violently bipolar shifts in mood and overly mannered dialogue. The writing is here, but the author is much harder to pinpoint.
If there's a chillier Lady Macbeth than Florence Pugh's callous, scheming madam then we'll pass on the resultant heating bill.
In Loco Parentis remains a lovely, likeable picture, but one that, ironically, might have benefitted from some old-school discipline.
A welcome, woofy warning against human speciesism.
When genre fans say "beware the 15A horror film", they're not talking about the scare quotient, but they could be talking about this film.
As one might expect, the horrors and the normalisation of same are deftly handled, even when the dialogue is overloaded with historical and political details.
See it, from between your fingers. But only if you're not in the throes of a midlife crisis.
Dash drew on her own family history to fashion Daughters of the Dust and throughout, there's an unshakable sense that the viewer is being called to bear witness. Heed the call.
The voice cast, too, are exceptional, enlivening dialogue that frequently sounds as though it has lost a little something in translation. If only the plot was worthy of their efforts.
As ever, the director has fashioned a lovely, appealing, lightly comic film that exists somewhere between late Ozu and early Spielberg.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Here is a film so poor, so half-arsed, and so contemptuous of its audience, that it screws up one of the great, (previously) infallible tropes of contemporary cinema: the David Hasslehoff cameo.
A pretty and problematic picture that leaves a sour taste in the mouth.

Fast, chaotic, and slightly out of step with contemporary Trumpian politics, the second feature from Cary Murnion and Jonathan Milott, brings little innovation to the civil apocalypse sub-genre, but it plays the beats cheerfully and effectively.
Marlina the Murderer is one of the most ravishingly beautiful films at Cannes.
movie_title: Marlina the Murderer in Four Acts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There are lame, crude jokes about bottoms and horologists. There is $230 million of CG effects that never look like anything more than pixels. And then there's Depp's panto drunkenness.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Crappy internationally co-produced animation, ahoy.
It holds its own, more than six decades on. If Giulietta Masina and Anthony Quinn's tragic two-step doesn't break your heart, then Nino Rota's score will.
A dazzlingly original fantasy conceit, worked to perfection.
Sahar Dowlatshahi, an actor who can emote with just gaze and eyebrows, beautifully complements [writer-director Behnam Behzad's] nuanced approach.
The film received a six-minute standing ovation at Cannes. We concur.
The softness and straightness of the performances obscure the monstrous melodrama underneath.
[Its] rawness, like the film's mesmerizingly grimy locales, has its own peculiar, aggressive charm.
Vladislav Opelyants' fluid cinematography and Ekaterina Scheglova's carefully-constructed everyday production design help emphasis the insidiousness of the titular antihero's brand of evil.
Beneath the grey veneer of rural realism, this is a magical film, one of the best you'll see this year.
[Dark Night] takes a macro approach to a disjointed society where guns are freely available and routinely glamorised.

Contemporary fans may be a little disappointed with 12 Bars' shut-up-and-play-the-hits focus on the earlier years. But even agnostics are likely to get caught up in the drama of his painful upbringing and boozy, self-destructive years.
movie_title: Eric Clapton: A Life in 12 Bars (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One for the fans. Fans of Blanchett and Kazimir Malevich's Suprematist Manifesto. Wherever they may be.
Stiller has visited this territory before, but never with such grating effectiveness. Following on from Ingrid Goes West; Brad's Status has dark fun with social media envy.
Walk with Me has several warm moments and should prove unmissable for fans of mindfulness. For the uninterested it's a test of faith.
Loosely inspired by Dendoune's remarkable achievement, this warm, likable film adds a romantic-comedy subplot to an already irresistible underdog tale.

The film's insistence that Barnum's freakshow is born from warm, fuzzy humanity and very contemporary notions of inclusivity is not just historically inaccurate, it's at odds with The Greatest Showman's extremely pretty idea of freakery. Pink hair?
At its best, Bright offers a clever critique of racism from a world of spells and sorcery. It's complicated.
Rather surprisingly, the second Jumanji caper has a "big idea" that extends beyond opportunistic brand recognition, with more than a nod to The Breakfast Club.
Craggy. But worth it for the views.

This is an extraordinarily beautiful film with lush, occasionally radical cinematography from Nelson Lik-wai Yu, profound things to say about the immigrant experience and a commanding performance from Zhao Tao.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: There are some good jokes - "I'll bet his parents aren't even related," one snooty horse scoffs at Ferdinand - and thoughts about animal sentience buried in a family caper that makes great use of Madrid landmarks in the final showdown.
At its best, Lu resembles a freestyle, teeny-bopper reworking of Hayao Miyazaki's similarly themed Ponyo.
movie_title: Lu Over the Wall (Yoake tsugeru Rû no uta) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: ... Better Watch Out is a delightfully nasty seasonal inversion, replete with carollers, decorations, themed jumpers and booze.
Steve Coogan has seldom been better or sourer as the irascible Paul.
An imaginative, gory, frenetic samurai carve-em-up, there's an irresistible energy about the project from the get-go.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: At 121 minutes, Battle of the Sexes occasionally drags, but it's the Hairy Legged Feminist-Male Chauvinist Pig showdown that we needed right now.
Goodall makes for fine company and every single tableau is breathtaking.

Whirlwind is something of a watchword for this inventive melodrama, which condenses into some 27 years into two hours, using daringly succinct, precise scenes, brilliantly spliced by editor Anne Klotz.

Unhappily, the "unprecedented access" afforded Greg Barker's often rudderless documentary largely consists of spin, pillow shots and political humblebragging. If you're hoping for Obama's very own West Wing spin-off, you'll soon be disappointed.

On paper, the mythology scans as complicated and dark, but in the capable hands of Academy Award winner Lee Unkrich and Pixar veteran Adrian Molina, Coco is accessible for even the youngest cinema patrons.
The real star is editor Nicholas De Toth, whose breakneck pacing, combined with Neeson's growling charisma, allows us to forget that not much in The Commuter makes a lick of sense.
There is, one suspects, a post-Cold War caper buried deep in this muddled, insanely boring film. But apparently it has no intention of surfacing or blowing its cover.
The moral of the story is that lesser Bergman still beats the pants of everything else. And The Touch is not, as we have been led to believe, lesser Bergman.
[Allison Janney's] undiluted unsentimentality is the perfect compliment for a sporting underdog movie that disobeys the rules.
No contemporary screen actor can do duplicity quite like the great Jacki Weaver.
With its cast of stalwarts and its fish-out-of-water narrative, Finding Your Feet can feel awfully familiar. Yet one would hesitate to call the same film cosy.
Come back, Daddy's Home 2; all is forgiven!

It sounds unbearably beatific; it's not. Irreplaceable You is not afraid to depict its central characters as unreasonable jerks....The lactose-intolerant have nothing to fear: no cheese was used in the making of this movie.
Even the likable stars, Jamie Sidegroin and Dakota Frontboob, can do nothing with material that has grown more tedious with each installment.
As a filmmaker, Franco has often tended toward high or performance art... The Disaster Artist allows for both these Francos to shine.
A bumbling excavator is not the worst idea, even if the new film fails to go the full Clouseau.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: One can't help but think that a movie chronicling Ayoub El Khazzani's journey toward that fateful day might be more interesting and useful.
Makala the film offers the kind of confrontational, truthful depiction of capitalism that ought to screen early and often in schools.
This animated theme-park ride won't scare genre veterans. But it'll do as a Pot Noodle snack until such horror entrées as Hereditary, Cold Hell, and Mom and Dad arrive.

Den of Thieves desperately wants to be Heat or The Killer when it grows up. Instead it's a daft, distant, drunken cousin to those pictures, but if you studiously avoid thinking about it, you can at least enjoy its moronic antics.
For those unfamiliar with the details, there's a neat narrative curve ball in the final act. Stupid: For sure. But futile? Hardly.
At least there's a camaraderie in knowing that your losses were for nothing.
As pointless and as unnecessarily long as the conflict that inspired it.
There's a touch of School of Rock with an Oom-Pah-Pah beat about this likeable, if lightweight comedy.
It defies comprehension that a director as accomplished as James Marsh... was involved in this woefully misconceived (and suspiciously long-delayed) period drama.
A wonderful cast make themselves at home against the music halls and maggoty, murky streets of 1880s London.

Susan Coyne's smart screenplay sees these real world antecedents rubbing shoulders with composite characters (notably Tara, an Irish maid with a flair for ghost stories) and Dickens getting into loud arguments with his fictional creations.
This textured sporting underdog narrative is greatly enlivened by the quality of its contributors.
Parry makes for an amiable travelling companion. Will his unabashed tree-hugging translate at a moment of peak climate-change denial? We do hope so.
movie_title: Tawai: A voice from the forest (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Even with Aleksei Rodionov's handsome monochrome cinematography, this is still just a bad, bad play. Let's not get this party started.
Lego Ninjago, conversely, can't sustain its central joke over an overlong 101 minutes. Everything is not quite awesome.
Bruckner's genre timing is spot on even if the finished film could be a tad more terrifying. Winningly witchy, nonetheless.
Cult classic? Try one of the greatest films ever made.
It all amounts to precisely nothing. It's not us, rom-com: it's you.
A character study that, much like its titular subject, refuses to conform to neat, trite expectations (as marvellously inhabited by Emily Beecham) is an appealing mess of uncertainties.
Géza Morcsányi's inventive wide-eyed turn steals the show.
movie_title: On Body and Soul (A Teströl és Lélekröl) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: [Shia] LaBeouf makes McEnroe his own, while costar Sverrir Gudnason does a remarkable approximation of Borg, right down to his walk and hockey-derived backhand.
[Angelina] Jolie's fourth narrative feature,confirms her as an exquisite craftswoman and an artist capable of tackling geopolitical complexities.
Even set against this chequered history, Manglehorn is an extremely odd picture.
At worst, the English dialogue sounds as if it were translated from dolphin noise into human.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: [The Villainness] is 2017's most breathtakingly unhinged action film.
Wind River's strong sense of place differentiates the film from the rest of the noir genre.
Ultimately, this war-torn drama fails to bring out the big guns.
There's something indescribably moving about watching grown men - at least one of whom has tried to cut another man in half - wail and sob.
Most commendably, Day of the Gusano captures the auditorium-shaking sensation of the live experience.
By the final act in this film, the randomness coalesces into something philosophical
movie_title: The Night Is Short, Walk On Girl (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Who needs Sex & the City 3? A brave film befitting its brave depiction of women.
It's misery porn at its most prettily dishonest, but against all odds, Harrelson, Brie Larson and a gaggle of talented child stars render it soapishly watchable.
Kate McCullough, one of our fines[t] - and most underrated cinematographers - savours each Roche build like a sommelier with a rarified Château Margaux.
Temporal loops and magic balls make for a strange, colourful combination.
movie_title: Fireworks, Should We See It from the Side or the Bottom? (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For an epic that might easily be titled "America", Mudbound is never heavy-handed or pretentious.
A film that really earns it's epic title and the lush Elvis Costello ballad over the final credits.
movie_title: Film Stars Don't Die in Liverpool (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It falls to Henry Cavill and Amy Adams to bring some semblance of humanity to the unlovely material. But it's not enough to save us from the balderdash.
Hugh Grant preens and puffs magnificently. Brendan Gleeson scowls and softens with similar aplomb. Both look to be having an absolute ball.

It's great that O'Toole and the others get a platform. But one can't help but wish that platform was a little more pleasingly movie-shaped. There's some good journalism here, particularly from The Detail's Barry McCaffrey, nonetheless.
A pleasingly discombobulating thriller.
It's Barry Keoghan who steals the show, thanks to a mouth-breathing, awkwardly gaited physicality and a breathless and-then-and-then playground game tone he uses to deliver his malevolent plan.
movie_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Director Stephen Chbosky, who previously adapted The Perks of Being a Wallflower (his own novel) for the screen has fashioned a irresistibly warm, unabashedly humanist family picture.
The resulting Grand Guignol will please fans, although the gore is never as groundbreaking as the drowning in pig entrails and reserve bear traps of old.
Perfect Blue is every Spice Girl, Shirelle and Supreme of yore refashioned and recast in Bergman's persona. An edgy new career, indeed.
If you can't enjoy [Happy Death Day], give up on film.
[Shirley Collins] is a ballad worth hearing.
Although this biopic is unfocused in parts, the live performances make for spectacular viewing.
Property of the State is a relentlessly grim chronicle of systemic failure and institutional abuse.
An extravagant flight of fancy that functions equally well as an anthropological curiosity, engrossing drama, feminist allegory, tart political satire and dire warning against xenophobia.

Daniel Ingram's big, Broadway musical numbers are epically-produced toe-tappers. The background designs are Ghibli-inspired excellent. And Emily Blunt couldn't invest Tempest with more tragedy and effort if she was doing an Ibsen play.
Brawl in Cell Block 99 is a comeback and a showcase for the bone-dry delivery of Vince Vaughn, who has never brooded bigger and badder than he does here.
Both Eili Harboe and Kaya Wilkins maintain an enigmatic, wide-eyed blankness as the possibly star-crossed lovers. Mesmerising and thrilling.
Here is a film that continually squanders its cast and your time.
This is the small-time, replete with unforgiving glare and hostile punters.
Where another filmmaker might have revelled in Uncertain's poverty and crime statistics, these directors find the sweetness in the saltiest of subjects and majesty in infested waters.
There are many things to recommend Catharine Corsini's erotically charged drama.
Everything about The Silent Storm suggests a screenplay was written entirely IN CAPITAL LETTERS. No "r" goes unrolled, no piece of furniture is unpounded.
So, here we are: five films in, and by the time we've finished with the introductions, there's hardly any time for a movie or jokes. Laugh? Not even once; not even close.
Befitting Hull's original project, Notes on Blindness is achingly, poignantly human.

The Hard Stop doesn't spoon-feed its audience. The film prefers driving around Tottenham's Broadwater Farm with the two riled, but grief-stricken men listening to stories from their childhood and teens.
Long shots of barren landscapes and domestic nothingness are punctured, in true Akerman style, with momentary eruptions of pain, poignancy and, most of all, love.
Anna shares DNA with the men-children of the Apatow oeuvre and yet Adult Life Skills is a unique specimen.
It's impossible to dislike NYSM2, a big blousy movie that is giddily in love with its own preposterousness.

Cinematographer Christos Karamanis boxes in the madness with disciplined framing. It is, perhaps entirely the point, that the film's shenanigans leave one yearning for the same sense of order to be imposed elsewhere.
Sweet Bean's gentle, quiet drama shares DNA with the work of Kawase's compatriot, Hirokazu Koreeda. Sweet by name, sweet by nature.
The great DOP Roger Deakins works hard to make cramped, dank interiors look cinematic. Cox's humour, meanwhile, compensates for the grim subject matter.
ny picture featuring Geoffrey Rush channelling King Lear as the patriarch god Ra while flying about in a spaceship can't be all bad.
A sprawl of beautifully cast characters -- a weasly pimp (Germano) here, a junkie moll (Scarano) there -- and their many intersections are deftly juggled, thanks to Patrizio Morane's darting cuts.
Me Before You has no interest in the realities of life with disability; it is, rather, yet another variant on a threadbare formula.
Too often, The Nice Guys feels like the Funniest Film of 1994. There are worse things.
What is this telenovela doing in a cinema?
Making terrific use of M Dujardin's prankster appeal, Up For Love doesn't care for accurate proportions when there's a short gag to be had at its leading man's expense.
movie_title: Up for Love (Un homme à la hauteur) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Malin Buska's pointedly manly performance as Kristina (a role that has been previously essayed by Greta Garbo and Liv Ullmann) -- all strides and swordplay -- is one of those heavily stylised turns that is either genius or folly.
The characterisation is particularly strong: the goal-driven, hard-working, clever and brave Sasha ultimately wins over even the most hard-hearted of navvies.
movie_title: Long Way North (Tout en haut du monde) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Rosi disguises the urgency of these unfolding horrors with a stately, procedural crawl. There is no political grandstanding or direct campaigning, but this is a call to arms from those left to ferry the corpses.
Crudup's Zimbardo shifts from ruthlessness to panic, but that shift isn't nearly as marked as what we observe among his subjects.
This smart, grown-up drama is one of those films that seems happier to start a conversation, rather than having the last word.
About 20 per cent less anarchy. 30 per cent more jokes, and 40 per cent more story would have made for better viewing.
Mostly, Bad Moms is remarkably astute about the pressures and neuroses of modern parenting.
There are moments when War Dogs approximates the effective politics-channelling comedy of The Big Short.

The CG might be a little algorithmic but this new animated feature based on the much-loved Asterix adventure Mansion of the Gods is a marked improvement on the same franchise's live actioners starring Gérard Depardieu.
movie_title: Asterix and Obelix: Mansion of the Gods (Astérix: Le domaine des dieux) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: More meaningfully, Tickled offers an anatomy of intimidation that feels particularly relevant for our post-Gamergate times.
Accompanying adults may notice that the plotting could be tighter and the animation could be more sophisticated, but at 87 minutes, Blinky at least knows when to say "Hooroo".
A double vinyl album and The David Brent Songbook is on the way. A fictional character's vanity project is still a vanity project.
movie_title: David Brent: Life on the Road (2017)

movie_review_blurb: By the time Catfight recycles its punchline for the third time, the power has gone out of its punch. But we'll never say no to a one-joke movie as long as it's a good joke.

It would have been nice to have examined more of Bergman's odd transatlantic career -- glimpses of an early screen test can only be described as ravishing -- but classic Hollywood buffs will be well-served, nonetheless.
movie_title: Ingrid Bergman in Her Own Words (Jag är Ingrid) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: There's something irrepressible about McCarthy's shtick. Her foul-mouthed rants are always amusing, even when they're not quite laugh-out-loud funny.

Talk about good timing. Having just scored the Palme d'Or at Cannes for I, Daniel Blake - he also won it in 2006 for The Wind that Shakes the Barley - Ken Loach receives the documentary treatment with this very fine overview of a chequered career.
movie_title: Versus: The Life and Films of Ken Loach (2016)

movie_review_blurb: One couldn't claim Risk is an unqualified success but there are enough such highlights to compensate for the lack of cogency.
The cinematography by Akiko Ashizawa ensures that their vacation is always lovely to behold, but almost everything else about this odd, elliptical drama is frustrating.
movie_title: Journey To The Shore (Kishibe No Tabi) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Unlikely as it sounds, this strangely compelling allegory is punctuated by nerve-wrecking action scenes, as the survivors battle against elements and circumstance.
This isn't as hard-hitting as Mungiu's other Cannes contenders, but the subtleties of quiet backslapping and knowing-a-guy turn out to be plenty dramatic.
Race is a classic underdog sports movie.
The quasi-Sapphic intensity of Anna and Marnie's relationship - recalling Ghost World or a benign Heavenly Creatures - is poetically and sensitively handled.
The mafia diaspora makes for interesting textures and Scamarcio's magnetism never wavers, but the smudged narrative simply doesn't work.
Colm McCarthy fashions a terrifying alt-future from confined spaces and group dynamics where another film-maker might have lazily summoned a CGI vista.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The terra incognita beneath the installations ensure much of what we see is a revelation. Despite the short running time, there's much to see here.
movie_title: Troublemakers: The Story of Land Art (2016)

movie_review_blurb: John Miller's good-natured picture makes a noble stab at yoking real-world social problems to capering.
Entertaining, informative and essential.
Wiig's depiction of a woman whose stories are apt to end with the declaration "then I went off my meds" is as disquieting as it is scarily accurate.
O'Connor once again proves that he can mine femininity just as effectively as he explored masculinity in Pride and Glory (2008) and Warrior (2011).
We're delighted to report that: you're a good movie, Charlie Brown.
If you're in the market for a tranquil, meditative holiday but can't quite pony up the cost, this surprisingly engaging film will do just as well.
Even a weird curveball coda can't undo the good work done by the filmmaker and a very fine quartet of thespians.
Even if the film worked - and it really doesn't - its existence surely represents one of the daftest studio miscalculations of all time.
Happily, 10 Cloverfield Lane proves a wildly effective white-knuckle affair, replete with twists, turns and terror.
Sing Street trades in a similar sort of heightened reality to that which energised Stanley Donen's post-war musicals.
50 Shades of Black does, at least, have to good grace to be 50 times more entertaining than the original.
Gaze in wonder at the beautiful woodcut-inspired landscapes, the 2D manga-style flashbacks, and the inventive choreography. Skidoosh, indeed.
From the brilliant mind of Charlie Kaufman comes the best film about hotel-related boredom since Lost in Translation. But with puppets.

Rohrwacher's recreation of the monotonous rhythms of low-tech farm life is every bit as attentive and diligent as the film's heroine. But the director's impressionistic approach to narrative does get a little frustrating.

Noonan and cinematographer Tom Comerford do splendid work making a comparatively short car drive look and feel like an epic road trip, and David Geraghty's score is one of the best film compositions of 2015.

Cub is characterised by terrific performances (especially from the pre-teen cast), playfully ghoulish bloodwork, and the most inventive instruments of death we've seen since the Saw franchise ran out of ideas.

The sheer jouissance of Vertov's experimentation in a film defined by odd angles, jump cuts, split screens, tracking shots, double exposure and... playful montage, might alone propel Man with a Movie Camera onto greatest film ever lists.

There is, for all the frivolity of her business, a gravitas and magnetism about Iris Apfel: she's smart and funny and sassy enough for the viewer to see past a life of privilege and walk-in wardrobes.
Succinct, handheld camerawork and deft performances amplify the drama's emotional clout.
This mess of tracking shots of deserts, roads and rotating love interests stubbornly refuses to coalesce into anything resembling a narrative film.
Animation veterans Fergal Reilly and Clay Kaytis ensure this Skittles-coloured universe is never less than zippy. But it's the cast that makes the movie.
The finished feature works well as a Hockney primer, but it's nothing we haven't seen before in the many TV documentaries made about the same artist over the years.
An ambitiously thorough yet quiet exploration of familial dysfunction.
Despite some moving contributions from family members, particularly Mapplethorpe's younger brother Edward, the film never really gets anywhere near its subject.
It ought to be too daft and random for its own good, but Brand New Testament is a book we can believe in. Hallelujah.
movie_title: The Brand New Testament (Le tout nouveau testament) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Engaging enough for the duration but muddled and ill-conceived.
Nasty indeed.
One can never be short of things to look at while Kurasawa's Ran is in the world.
Prepare for feel-bad cinema. Larraín skilfully manipulates the viewer to feel sympathy for the priests and revulsion for their victim.

This is very much a Matthias Schoenaerts picture. Having been hopelessly miscast in a series of rather poor English language pictures, Disorder's soulful brute allows him to revisit the brooding and hulking of Bullhead and Rust and Bone.
Save a final swashbuckling sequence in which Crusoe and chums fend off pirates, there's nothing to match, say, that spooky moment when the hero finds footprints in the sand.
Just when you imagined that the courtroom drama had no particular place left to go, along comes Chaitanya Tamhane's fiendishly clever debut feature.
If the characters on screen aren't too bothered, then what hope for the viewer?
There are commendable lessons here about being resilient and resourceful and kind, but you'll have fun learning them.
Ethan Hawke puts in a career- best turn as jazz trumpeter Chet Baker in this imaginatively structured biopic.
This extraordinary chronicle, characterised by extraordinary access and dozens of "No, really?" moments, offers a terrifying and cautionary tale of political hubris.

This is unmissable.

Like so much drug-related humor, it's best suited for viewers who happen to be really, really wasted.

Bloodlust is both an animation landmark and a beautifully realized film.
Nominally speaking, Another Earth is science fiction, but it's more concerned with mood and metaphysics than science.

The Syrian Bride becomes an overtly political movie, but with all its loose threads and random directions, it feels more like the pilot for an unmade miniseries.
Whenever it hits its stride, it's a well-acted, vividly executed, full-speed-ahead special-effects extravaganza that puts as much bang as possible into every remaining scene.

movie_title: The Promise (Master of Crimson Armor) (Wu ji) (2005)

As with his last film, 2002's Equilibrium, Wimmer borrows all his best ideas from other movies . . . then spackles over his half-assed plot with a shiny aesthetic.

...while the visuals are terrific, the plot is a distracting clunker that feels like it was written one line at a time by a bunch of overexcited fan-board commentators playing a round-robin storytelling game.

movie_review_blurb: In this case, what looks like an ambitious film-school project, complete with heavy-handed sincerity, experimental camera style, and an overplayed central metaphor, becomes gently lyrical and melancholy.

Reasonably absorbing.

It's an effective experiment and a hackle-raising drama, and it's far better controlled than De Palma's last film, the flailing noir mess The Black Dahlia.

In December, Cusack will be back on screen in Grace Is Gone, another portrait of a grieving widower struggling to raise children. Viewers may want to hold out to see him in a film that maintains its sensitivity all the way through.

movie_review_blurb: Eggers' book pushes past satire into dark farce, where the story's hyperbole feels more like a gag than a coherent warning about the future. The film version doesn't even feel pointed enough to be satire.

It's okay to cover the classics; practically every musician wants to play around with their idols' work. But Life feels like a strictly subtractive cover of Alien that loses too much of what made it memorable, and doesn't bring enough new to the table.
It doesn't follow through on many of its gambits. It's much more dedicated to copycatting a classic, while making it bigger, louder, and broader.
It could have used a few more weeks on the drafting table, to sharpen its ideas and give it priorities other than gore.
Small-budget indie films often have to limit their scope and their sights, but Bokeh takes in enough of the protagonists' deserted, lonely world to feel completely convincing.
Like so much of Key & Peele's comedy, Get Out is refreshing in its naked, frank aggression about confronting racial issues, with comedy, drama, and sharp, unsparing insight.
The weight of graphic, grotesque violence hangs over the entire movie. But the daring emotional violence lingers longer, well after the lights go down on the final shot.

Hiccups aside, though, The Endless rapidly develops from a mysterious, elliptical story about cult survivors and strained relationships into a much larger and stranger movie, essentially the Aliens to Resolution's original Alien.
John Wick: Chapter 2 is an enjoyable enough expansion on the first film. But its final-act setup for John Wick: Chapter 3 is more trying than promising.
The Shape of Water is a breathless film, anchored by [Sally] Hawkins' visible, ardent longing for connection, and her fierce defiance when the things she loves are threatened

... it's a reminder that King's biggest strengths lie in his unparalleled ability to build tension, create atmosphere, and tell a direct and brutal story, not in his ability to launch profitable many-branched franchises.
The human frailties behind the game avatars is a reliable well of humor for Ready Player One, and the script takes full, hilarious advantage.
It's a pretty take on the story, but it's also a frustratingly safe and squishy one.
Annihilation is a portentous movie, and a cerebral one. It's gorgeous and immersive, but distancing. It's exciting more in its sheer ambition and its distinctiveness than in its actual action.
The characters are all painfully sincere - but they're also generic, bland, and barely developed. When they inevitably start dying, there's no sense of loss, either for the audience or the crew.
One of the film's greatest values, though, is as a helpful checklist for cinephiles who want to see more terrific films made by women.
It's a merciless film, crafted for maximum effect.

That's the great joy of Come Inside My Mind: not getting a fundamentally new understanding of Williams, but just watching him react in the moment with a sense of humor that always seemed to come directly from the id.
movie_title: Robin Williams: Come Inside My Mind (2018)

movie_review_blurb: There's so much to love about Downsizing, in its self-aware dialogue, its consciously corny gags, its sense of creativity and adventure, and its vivid creation of an entire new world.
Beyond Skyline becomes an enjoyably loopy thrill-ride, full of sudden shifts and turns.
Justice League winds up feeling so much like a straw poll for viewers, with a mishmash of everything they might want, all run together.
Instead, this is yet another cinematic Frankenstein's monster, stitched together out of scavenged parts, and shocked back to life for no clear or compelling reason.
But like Argo, Salyut-7 is an edge-of-the-seat experience even when it veers into obviously exaggerated territory.
... at heart, the story is about excitement, wonder, and exploring the world.
Radius is a high-concept movie from start to finish, and it relies on surprises to keep the story moving.
Anna and the Apocalypse is an entertaining blast of fresh air that just happens to include a fine spray of blood.
Writer-director Mike Flanagan and co-writer Jeff Howard have turned Gerald's Game into one of the most compelling, eerie, memorable Stephen King adaptations to date.

[Director Rian Johnson] doesn't radically reinvent Star Wars... But he does dig into the impulses behind the new trilogy's younger characters, cracking them open and examining their psychology in a way Star Wars rarely has.
The biggest problem with all of this is the overwhelming sense of apathy the film brings to almost everything.
An endlessly surprising little charmer of a film that makes sincerity and sweetness into a cinematic virtue again.
[Melanie Lynskey's] a huge asset to the movie, and so is Elijah Wood, playing his fragile-but-kinda-unsettling vibe to the hilt.
movie_title: I don't feel at home in this world anymore. (2017)

movie_review_blurb: First, the film doesn't have any particularly intelligent or clever answers to its own what-if premise. Second, it's operating in the shadow of other science-fiction films that do engage with the same questions.

The film never comes up with a mission statement or a message that might tie together its wandering scenes, or explain its vague melancholy. In the end, it feels like a life-support system for a single perfect scene .
Don't Breathe is still a thrilling experience that effectively puts the audience in the protagonists' place: uncertain, cringing, afraid to even breathe because of the potential consequences.
David Mackenzie's terrifically tense Western Hell or High Water is set in the present, but it keeps emphasizing that in some key ways, life hasn't changed in West Texas since pioneer days.

It doesn't necessarily fall to this film to define what a villain's journey really means. But like its characters, it's free to operate on its own terms, and it'd be a much stronger story if it took full advantage of that freedom.
The film packs in so much material that it's bound to have dead ends and weak spots, but its confidence in its provocations is compelling.
Bourne is numbing in its relentless, repetitive pursuit sequences, some of which add absolutely nothing to the story except wrecked cars and extra minutes.

At 132 minutes, the story drags to the point where even natural beauty and sweet intimacy start to wear on the nerves. Cianfrance pushes too hard for his audience's emotional response, with little nuance and strange selectivity.

Until a richer villain and more thought-out story come along, we at least have this chapter, which offers fans of the original Trek world some of the things they've most wanted: space to enjoy all their old heroes, and reasons to respect them again.
Like so many Allen films, it feels like it was made primarily for his therapist, and letting the rest of the world in to see it and make their own diagnoses is an afterthought.
Ghostbusters is a lively, hilarious crowd-pleaser, which is all that's really required of a big summer action comedy.
Like What We Do In The Shadows, Wilderpeople is laugh-out-loud funny and full of left-turn surprises.

Thompson's leads are so natural in their roles, and his filmmaking is so immediate and intimate, that King Jack is instantly absorbing.

Warcraft won't go down in history as a ringing success, but people who see it aren't likely to forget it easily, either. It's much more of a commercial endeavor than Jones' other films, but it doesn't abandon art by the wayside.
It's still something distinctive and different in a sea of shiny mirrors, all reflecting the same slick CGI style back at each other.
Louis Drax shoves magic and monsters into a story that's already overpacked with grindhouse violence, a police procedural, a queasy romance, and incoherent social commentary.
It's only appropriate that the film is as competent, efficient, and mildly dull as the people it celebrates.

It's not enough to acknowledge that film is doing moviegoers a service in telling a story they may not find familiar. It also has to be acknowledged that it tells it in a wearyingly familiar, conventional way.

movie_title: Give Me Future (Give Me Future: Major Lazer in Cuba) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's the kind of film that's guaranteed to make people angry, but it's still unmissable.

The entire film has the same blue-and-black color palette, and it gets really samey and visually dreary. It means visibility in a lot of scenes is pretty poor.

It's a melancholy final visit in light of the recent death of both its subjects. But it's still a rare chance for viewers to sneak behind those weird, eccentric compound gates, and hang out as if they were part of the family.
movie_title: Bright Lights: Starring Carrie Fisher and Debbie Reynolds (2017)

movie_review_blurb: For a mainstream supernatural-fantasy war film, Spectral is curiously devoted to rhapsodizing about science, and considering the moral implications of scientific discovery.
[Pesce] creates some extreme beauty out of ugliness, and he builds amazing tension out of quiet moments and simple movement.

If nothing else, it's fun to see that there's a Potterverse outside Harry Potter himself. His world has always been big enough to sustain other stories. Finally, it has a chance to.
movie_title: Fantastic Beasts and Where to Find Them (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The bizarre fortune-cookie philosophy of its coda just emphasizes how impoverished this film feels when it comes to unifying themes, or a big picture that would find meaning in all the little incidents.

It feels like a curio -- not an eerie, unexplained one, like the vintage photographs that inspired Riggs' Miss Peregrine trilogy, but a dated and familiar one, yanked out of the dusty old boxes piled up in the Burton archive.
movie_title: Miss Peregrine's Home for Peculiar Children (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mira Nair's inspirational chess drama Queen of Katwe is remarkable in the simplest but most profound way: it's an American film about Africa that doesn't feel like it was made by tourists.
One of Moonlight's remarkable strengths is how completely it avoids preaching, after-school messaging, or pat cinematic answers.
It feels odd to say this, but the primary problem with Christopher Guest's latest improvised-dialogue mockumentary is that it just isn't mean enough.

The craft of La La Land is impeccable, from the energetically active camera to the staging and production design that re-creates the past without feeling dated. But there's a reckless cockiness to the production as well.
The joy of American Honey is how easy, relaxed, and sprawling it feels.

It's a patient film, and it requires some patience from its audience. But its rewards are gentle and winning, and for once, a cinematic history lesson that doesn't feel artificial and processed in every pore.
Hidden somewhere in the murky shadows of The Conjuring 2 is an utterly terrifying 90-minute horror movie that doesn't waste time on repetition, doubts, sidebar stories, or long conversations.
Like Ghibli's features, Kingdom is a friendly, elegiac, approachable movie. But it lacks the studio's well-polished sense of energy and commitment.
movie_title: The Kingdom of Dreams and Madness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: You can't play a symphony with a single note. With Apocalypse, Singer never gets around to varying his single, gloomy, dreary tune.

The acting is sometimes shockingly bad, but generally the script doesn't ask much of the actors, and the combat is effectively staged and often thrilling.

If no one behind the scenes cared enough about the padding around the money sequences to make it original, believable, or interesting, why is there so much of it?

The filmmakers mistakenly think nothing is silly if it's done with a grim enough facial expression.

A barely feature-length diversion that lacks the energy to grip younger viewers or the depth to impress adults, but it earns respect with its makers' dedication to old-school craft.

In Ben Lewin's The Sessions, John Hawkes takes on the kind of role that earns Academy Awards, in the kind of film that doesn't.

It's unchallenging fun for a younger crowd, but adults might feel like they're staring down a colorful 24-piece board puzzle, trying to figure out how such a simple activity could be drawn out over 90 minutes.
Beautiful Creatures is an oddball creation: a morality play with no basic understanding of morality.

Takes its premise painfully literally, resulting in a series of unlikely developments guaranteed to get hardcore zombie-movie fans frothing with rage -- if they don't doze off first.
It isn't a movie so much as a mechanical process.

Lightning is a funny, fast-moving movie, packed with barbed one-liners, goofy hyperbole, and all the oversized exasperation of teen angst. But it's too acid, particularly where Colfer is concerned.
A rich portrait of how individual lives progress, and how age shapes expectations and experience.
Jackman is performing in a drama, Crowe on his concert stage, and Hathaway alone in her room. It's a collection of performances rather than a story.
Jack Reacher isn't much of a man, and Jack Reacher isn't the story of a man. It's mythmaking for self-satisfied sociopaths.
In its final half-hour, it pulls all the threads together, and a breathtaking bigger picture finally comes into focus.
At its best, it recaptures the Rings movies' breadth, detail, and staggering sense of beauty.
While the scenes don't always fit together thematically or tonally, each one is its own polished gem.
Rise Of The Guardians boasts a great deal of visual energy and amounts to a lot of fun ...

More than another standard cutesy reference-fest with some exciting chases and an eventual upbeat message.

The film spends a great deal of its focus on fights that stretch out to Lord Of The Rings length, but without LOTR-level effects or panache.
Pirates! comes with all the usual Aardman strengths intact, particularly the sense that its characters and creators alike are too good-hearted and sweet to nitpick.
All of Mirror Mirror is visually striking, even when it works on no other levels.
It never lacks for the arid, vista-prone beauty of a classic Western, or for a sense of lived-in wear and tear that remains convincing even though it's more stylized than realistic.

It's too focused on capturing a bygone moment and portraying it as the present, while the band and the couple have inevitably moved on, to a new album, a high-profile suicide at one of their concerts, a band hiatus, and well beyond.

For a film that takes place in such a cold locale, it all feels awfully warmed-over.
[Showcases] a restless, ambitious talent who invariably puts an idiosyncratic stamp on his material, no matter how ordinary it is at the core.

Has the faults of raucous recent scatological comedies like Bad Teacher, Horrible Bosses, and The Hangover Part II with none of their redeeming facets.
Like Parker's character, I Don't Know How She Does It wants to have it all, and has trouble committing to a course of action.

Even when making movies for small children, Studio Ghibli produces stories that are more emotionally sophisticated, and less philosophically polarized, than most adult fare.
A heady wonder for fans of the music, the era, or visual creative art in general.

Watching the film is strangely like looking at the same three still frames of supernatural battles over and over for 90 minutes.

While it's essentially just another slick Spielberg action machine, it's operating effectively on all cylinders throughout.
It's a beautifully shot, beautifully acted piece of fluff.

Effectively a strategy guide and commercial in vaguely filmic form.

movie_review_blurb: I, Frankenstein looks suspiciously like it was conceived more as a ready-made franchise property than as a strong individual story.

Mostly the problem is that every aspect of The Giver feels both painfully familiar and like an awkward, unsupportable stretch.

movie_review_blurb: Time Bandits is one of Gilliam's more chaotic films, which is really saying something, but his six time-bandits fill the screen with fractious energy.

It's recognizably the work of an idiosyncratic artist dealing in bizarre caricature, and exploring weird ideas.

movie_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night (2014)

Stahelski stands a bit back from the fights and keeps them clear and coherent, rather than impressionistic.

The entire film vibrates with understated tension, but almost never raises its voice above a hissed threat or a discomfited mutter.
Like The Daily Show, Rosewater makes uncomfortable political realities into wry but uproarious jokes.

[P]icking and choosing the worthwhile moments out of this disorganized grab bag of tones, gags, and ideas feels like picking through a cheap assortment of mixed nuts, looking for the occasional pecan among peanuts.

No amount of shoehorned-in razzle-dazzle can keep this forced fable from feeling like a shadow of Kon's early work.

Narratively, Trance is questionable, but Boyle and Hodges whisk past all the unlikely developments with enough verve and style to keep audiences from thinking too hard until after they've left the theater.
Jackson's The Hobbit...is shaping up as a weirdly overblown attempt to force a much smaller story into the epic size of his previous movies.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Niccols always picks unusual, intriguing projects, and gives them a distinctive look, but the emotional core of his stories sometimes escapes him.

Moment for moment, Upside Down is the most embarrassing, hilarious, obliviously stupid movie since M. Night Shyamalan's The Happening, and its constant pursuit of a striking image over any other consideration undermines it at every turn.

movie_title: El artista y la modelo (The Artist and the Model) (2013)

movie_review_blurb: There's a sly brilliance to the way Dupieux responds to audience expectation by repeatedly, pointedly violating Chekhov's Law.
A messy, confused, over-the-top mixture of brutality and sick comedy, puckishness and ugliness, self-awareness and tone-deafness.
